titleStmt.author: Reynolds, John

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To the Right Honourable Lord, Aubignuy, health eternall.
analytic.author: Reynolds, John

monogr.title: Dolarnys primerose. Or the first part of the passionate hermit : wherein is expressed the liuely passions of zeale and loue, with an alluding discourse to valours ghost. Both pleasant and profitable, if iudiciously read, and rightly vnderstood. Written by a practitioner in poesie, and a stranger amongst poets, which causeth him dread this sentence: Nihil ad parmenonis suem
monogr.author: Reynolds, John

div.head: To the Right Honourable Lord, Aubignuy, health eternall.

lg.l: WHat nere seene gemme, shall I deuise to set,
Vpon your helme, your temples to ingert▪
What trophe rare, what wreath or Coronet,
O let me pollish, some nere written line,
To fit your worth, for worldlings to peruse:
And place it in, that loftie crest of thine,
Whose siluer showers, nourisheth my muse.
Making them spring, as flow'rs from frosty earth,
With Aprill deaws, the worlds broad eye to view:
Which else had died, and nere obtained birth,
Had they not gain'd, incouragement of you.
Base are the thoughts, that longs to write and dare not▪
Then if you smile, let others frowne, (I care not.)

closer.signed: Your Lordships euer humbly deuoted: Iohn Raynolds.
